Recommended Proteins.name: MAPT
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Microtubule-associated protein tau; Promotes microtubule assembly and stability, and might be involved in the establishment and maintenance of neuronal polarity. The C-terminus binds axonal microtubules while the N-terminus binds neural plasma membrane components, suggesting that tau functions as a linker protein between both. Axonal polarity is predetermined by TAU/MAPT localization (in the neuronal cell) in the domain of the cell body defined by the centrosome. The short isoforms allow plasticity of the cytoskeleton whereas the longer isoforms may preferentially play a role in its st [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: CAMK2A
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase type II subunit alpha; Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase that functions autonomously after Ca(2+)/calmodulin-binding and autophosphorylation, and is involved in synaptic plasticity, neurotransmitter release and long-term potentiation. Member of the NMDAR signaling complex in excitatory synapses, it regulates NMDAR-dependent potentiation of the AMPAR and therefore excitatory synaptic transmission (By similarity). Regulates dendritic spine development. Also regulates the migration of developing neurons. Phosphorylates the transcriptio [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: GSKIP
Recommended Proteins.annotation: GSK3B-interacting protein; A-kinase anchoring protein for GSK3B and PKA that regulates or facilitates their kinase activity towards their targets. The ternary complex enhances Wnt-induced signaling by facilitating the GSK3B- and PKA-induced phosphorylation of beta-catenin leading to beta-catenin degradation and stabilization respectively. Upon cAMP activation, the ternary complex contributes to neuroprotection against oxidative stress-induced apoptosis by facilitating the PKA-induced phosphorylation of DML1 and PKA-induced inactivation of GSK3B. During neurite outgrowth promotes neuron [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: GSK3B
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Glycogen synthase kinase-3 beta; Constitutively active protein kinase that acts as a negative regulator in the hormonal control of glucose homeostasis, Wnt signaling and regulation of transcription factors and microtubules, by phosphorylating and inactivating glycogen synthase (GYS1 or GYS2), EIF2B, CTNNB1/beta-catenin, APC, AXIN1, DPYSL2/CRMP2, JUN, NFATC1/NFATC, MAPT/TAU and MACF1. Requires primed phosphorylation of the majority of its substrates. In skeletal muscle, contributes to insulin regulation of glycogen synthesis by phosphorylating and inhibiting GYS1 activity and hence glyc [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: GSK3A
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Glycogen synthase kinase-3 alpha; Constitutively active protein kinase that acts as a negative regulator in the hormonal control of glucose homeostasis, Wnt signaling and regulation of transcription factors and microtubules, by phosphorylating and inactivating glycogen synthase (GYS1 or GYS2), CTNNB1/beta-catenin, APC and AXIN1. Requires primed phosphorylation of the majority of its substrates. Contributes to insulin regulation of glycogen synthesis by phosphorylating and inhibiting GYS1 activity and hence glycogen synthesis. Regulates glycogen metabolism in liver, but not in muscle (B [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: SIRPA
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type substrate 1; Immunoglobulin-like cell surface receptor for CD47. Acts as docking protein and induces translocation of PTPN6, PTPN11 and other binding partners from the cytosol to the plasma membrane. Supports adhesion of cerebellar neurons, neurite outgrowth and glial cell attachment. May play a key role in intracellular signaling during synaptogenesis and in synaptic function (By similarity). Involved in the negative regulation of receptor tyrosine kinase-coupled cellular responses induced by cell adhesion, growth factors or insulin. Medi [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: PTPN6
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type 6; Modulates signaling by tyrosine phosphorylated cell surface receptors such as KIT and the EGF receptor/EGFR. The SH2 regions may interact with other cellular components to modulate its own phosphatase activity against interacting substrates. Together with MTUS1, induces UBE2V2 expression upon angiotensin II stimulation. Plays a key role in hematopoiesis.

Recommended Proteins.name: CEP350
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Centrosome-associated protein 350; Plays an essential role in centriole growth by stabilizing a procentriolar seed composed of at least, SASS6 and CENPJ. Required for anchoring microtubules to the centrosomes and for the integrity of the microtubule network. Recruits PPARA to discrete subcellular compartments and thereby modulates PPARA activity. Required for ciliation.

Recommended Proteins.name: CEP192
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Centrosomal protein of 192 kDa; Required for mitotic centrosome maturation and bipolar spindle assembly. Appears to be a major regulator of pericentriolar material (PCM) recruitment, centrosome maturation, and centriole duplication. Centrosome- specific activating scaffold for AURKA and PLK1.

Recommended Proteins.name: HIP1
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Huntingtin-interacting protein 1; Plays a role in clathrin-mediated endocytosis and trafficking. Involved in regulating AMPA receptor trafficking in the central nervous system in an NMDA-dependent manner (By similarity). Regulates presynaptic nerve terminal activity (By similarity). Enhances androgen receptor (AR)- mediated transcription. May act as a proapoptotic protein that induces cell death by acting through the intrinsic apoptosis pathway. Binds 3-phosphoinositides (via ENTH domain). May act through the ENTH domain to promote cell survival by stabilizing receptor tyrosine kinases [...]

Recommended Proteins.name: KIF2A
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Kinesin-like protein KIF2A; Plus end-directed microtubule-dependent motor required for normal brain development. May regulate microtubule dynamics during axonal growth. Required for normal progression through mitosis. Required for normal congress of chromosomes at the metaphase plate. Required for normal spindle dynamics during mitosis. Promotes spindle turnover. Implicated in formation of bipolar mitotic spindles. Has microtubule depolymerization activity.

Recommended Proteins.name: PTBP1
Recommended Proteins.annotation: Polypyrimidine tract-binding protein 1; Plays a role in pre-mRNA splicing and in the regulation of alternative splicing events. Activates exon skipping of its own pre- mRNA during muscle cell differentiation. Binds to the polypyrimidine tract of introns. May promote RNA looping when bound to two separate polypyrimidine tracts in the same pre-mRNA. May promote the binding of U2 snRNP to pre-mRNA. Cooperates with RAVER1 to modulate switching between mutually exclusive exons during maturation of the TPM1 pre- mRNA. Represses the splicing of MAPT/Tau exon 10. In case of infection by picorn [...]

properties.annotation: Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase type II subunit alpha; Calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase that functions autonomously after Ca(2+)/calmodulin-binding and autophosphorylation, and is involved in synaptic plasticity, neurotransmitter release and long-term potentiation. Member of the NMDAR signaling complex in excitatory synapses, it regulates NMDAR-dependent potentiation of the AMPAR and therefore excitatory synaptic transmission (By similarity). Regulates dendritic spine development. Also regulates the migration of developing neurons. Phosphorylates the transcriptio [...]

Relationships.explanation: The interaction between MAPT and CAMK2A is relevant as CAMK2A phosphorylates MAPT. This phosphorylation impacts MAPT's role in microtubule stability and neuronal polarity, aligning with the query's focus on phosphorylation pathways.

properties.annotation: GSK3B-interacting protein; A-kinase anchoring protein for GSK3B and PKA that regulates or facilitates their kinase activity towards their targets. The ternary complex enhances Wnt-induced signaling by facilitating the GSK3B- and PKA-induced phosphorylation of beta-catenin leading to beta-catenin degradation and stabilization respectively. Upon cAMP activation, the ternary complex contributes to neuroprotection against oxidative stress-induced apoptosis by facilitating the PKA-induced phosphorylation of DML1 and PKA-induced inactivation of GSK3B. During neurite outgrowth promotes neuron [...]

Relationships.explanation: The interaction is not relevant to the query. GSKIP does not directly phosphorylate MAPT (tau). Instead, GSKIP regulates GSK3B and PKA activity, which indirectly impacts phosphorylation events. No direct interaction path is found.

properties.annotation: Glycogen synthase kinase-3 beta; Constitutively active protein kinase that acts as a negative regulator in the hormonal control of glucose homeostasis, Wnt signaling and regulation of transcription factors and microtubules, by phosphorylating and inactivating glycogen synthase (GYS1 or GYS2), EIF2B, CTNNB1/beta-catenin, APC, AXIN1, DPYSL2/CRMP2, JUN, NFATC1/NFATC, MAPT/TAU and MACF1. Requires primed phosphorylation of the majority of its substrates. In skeletal muscle, contributes to insulin regulation of glycogen synthesis by phosphorylating and inhibiting GYS1 activity and hence glyc [...]

Relationships.explanation: The interaction is relevant. GSKIP interacts with GSK3B, facilitating its kinase activity. GSK3B phosphorylates MAPT directly, impacting Wnt signaling, glucose homeostasis, and neuron function. Thus, the path aligns with the query.

properties.annotation: Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type 6; Modulates signaling by tyrosine phosphorylated cell surface receptors such as KIT and the EGF receptor/EGFR. SIRPA induces PTPN6 translocation to the plasma membrane, where PTPN6 modulates signaling by tyrosine-phosphorylated receptors. properties.annotation: Centrosome-associated protein 350; Plays an essential role in centriole growth by stabilizing a procentriolar seed composed of at least, SASS6 and CENPJ. properties.annotation: Centrosomal protein of 192 kDa; Required for mitotic centrosome maturation and bipolar spindle assembly. properties.annotation: Kinesin-like protein KIF2A; Plus end-directed microtubule-dependent motor required for normal brain development. May regulate microtubule dynamics during axonal growth. Path Details.explanation: The path MAPT -> GSKIP -> GSK3B is partially relevant. While GSKIP does not directly phosphorylate MAPT, it regulates GSK3B, which directly phosphorylates MAPT. This suggests an indirect regulatory mechanism via GSKIP, impacting MAPT phosphorylation through GSK3B's kinase activity, influencing key cellular processes like neuron function and Wnt signaling.
Path Details.details:
MAPT -> GSKIP:
The interaction is not relevant to the query. GSKIP does not directly phosphorylate MAPT (tau). Instead, GSKIP regulates GSK3B and PKA activity, which indirectly impacts phosphorylation events. No direct interaction path is found.

GSKIP -> GSK3B:
The interaction is relevant. GSKIP interacts with GSK3B, facilitating its kinase activity. GSK3B phosphorylates MAPT directly, impacting Wnt signaling, glucose homeostasis, and neuron function. Thus, the path aligns with the query.

MAPT -> GSKIP:
The interaction is not relevant to the query.

GSKIP -> GSK3A:
The interaction is relevant. GSKIP regulates GSK3A activity by anchoring it, and GSK3A phosphorylates MAPT. This pathway explains how GSKIP influences MAPT phosphorylation indirectly via GSK3A.

Path Details.explanation: The path 'MAPT -> SIRPA -> PTPN6' is not relevant because SIRPA does not phosphorylate MAPT directly. While the interaction between SIRPA and PTPN6 is relevant as it affects signaling pathways, there is no direct evidence that PTPN6 phosphorylates MAPT. Therefore, the path does not meet the query requirements.
Path Details.details:
MAPT -> SIRPA:
The interaction between MAPT and SIRPA is not relevant to the query since SIRPA does not directly phosphorylate MAPT. SIRPA functions as a docking protein, not a kinase, thus no direct phosphorylation occurs.

SIRPA -> PTPN6:
The interaction between SIRPA and PTPN6 is relevant. SIRPA induces PTPN6 translocation to the plasma membrane, where PTPN6 modulates signaling by tyrosine-phosphorylated receptors. This interaction can impact downstream signaling pathways, potentially affecting MAPT phosphorylation.

The interaction is not relevant. There is no direct information suggesting that CEP350 phosphorylates MAPT. Both proteins are involved in microtubule dynamics but lack direct phosphorylation linkage.

The interaction between CEP350 and CEP192 is relevant as both proteins are involved in centrosome maturation and microtubule organization. CEP192 recruits and activates kinases like AURKA and PLK1, which can potentially influence MAPT phosphorylation indirectly.

proteins.name: KIF2A
proteins.annotation: Kinesin-like protein KIF2A; Plus end-directed microtubule-dependent motor required for normal brain development. May regulate microtubule dynamics during axonal growth. Required for normal progression through mitosis. Required for normal congress of chromosomes at the metaphase plate. Required for normal spindle dynamics during mitosis. Promotes spindle turnover. Implicated in formation of bipolar mitotic spindles. Has microtubule depolymerization activity.

properties.annotation: Kinesin-like protein KIF2A; Plus end-directed microtubule-dependent motor required for normal brain development. May regulate microtubule dynamics during axonal growth. Required for normal progression through mitosis. Required for normal congress of chromosomes at the metaphase plate. Required for normal spindle dynamics during mitosis. Promotes spindle turnover. Implicated in formation of bipolar mitotic spindles. Has microtubule depolymerization activity.

relationships.explanation: The provided interaction is not relevant. MAPT (tau) does not phosphorylate KIF2A. Instead, both proteins are involved in microtubule dynamics but do not directly interact in a phosphorylation pathway.

Path Details.explanation: The path 'MAPT -> SIRPA' is not relevant because there is no direct evidence that SIRPA phosphorylates MAPT. Therefore, the interaction does not satisfy the query's requirement for the end protein to phosphorylate MAPT. Additionally, without any direct phosphorylation relationship or clear biological mechanism connecting these proteins, it cannot be recommended.
Path Details.details:
MAPT -> SIRPA:
The interaction between MAPT and SIRPA is not relevant since no direct evidence suggests that SIRPA phosphorylates MAPT. The provided annotations do not indicate a phosphorylation relationship between these proteins.

properties.annotation: Tyrosine-protein phosphatase non-receptor type substrate 1; Immunoglobulin-like cell surface receptor for CD47. Acts as docking protein and induces translocation of PTPN6, PTPN11 and other binding partners from the cytosol to the plasma membrane. Supports adhesion of cerebellar neurons, neurite outgrowth and glial cell attachment. May play a key role in intracellular signaling during synaptogenesis and in synaptic function (By similarity). Involved in the negative regulation of receptor tyrosine kinase-coupled cellular responses induced by cell adhesion, growth factors or insulin. Medi [...]

Path Details.explanation: The interaction MAPT -> PTBP1 is not relevant. PTBP1 represses MAPT exon 10 splicing, but there is no evidence of phosphorylation involved. The query specifically asks for phosphorylation, which is not addressed here.

proteins.name: PTBP1
proteins.annotation: Polypyrimidine tract-binding protein 1; Plays a role in pre-mRNA splicing and in the regulation of alternative splicing events. Activates exon skipping of its own pre- mRNA during muscle cell differentiation. Binds to the polypyrimidine tract of introns. May promote RNA looping when bound to two separate polypyrimidine tracts in the same pre-mRNA. May promote the binding of U2 snRNP to pre-mRNA. Cooperates with RAVER1 to modulate switching between mutually exclusive exons during maturation of the TPM1 pre- mRNA. Represses the splicing of MAPT/Tau exon 10. In case of infection by picorn [...]

Path Details.explanation: The path 'MAPT -> CEP350' is not relevant as there is no evidence that CEP350 directly phosphorylates MAPT. Both proteins are involved in microtubule-related processes but lack a direct phosphorylation interaction. Therefore, this path cannot satisfy the query of finding a protein that phosphorylates MAPT.
Path Details.details:
MAPT -> CEP350:
This interaction is not relevant because there is no evidence that CEP350 directly phosphorylates MAPT. Both proteins are involved in microtubule-related processes but lack direct phosphorylation interaction.

properties.annotation: Centrosome-associated protein 350; Plays an essential role in centriole growth by stabilizing a procentriolar seed composed of at least, SASS6 and CENPJ. Required for anchoring microtubules to the centrosomes and for the integrity of the microtubule network. Recruits PPARA to discrete subcellular compartments and thereby modulates PPARA activity. Required for ciliation.

relationships.explanation: This interaction is not relevant because there is no evidence that CEP350 directly phosphorylates MAPT. Both proteins are involved in microtubule-related processes but lack direct phosphorylation interaction.
